_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:
Facility Contact:    Tom Catlin    Phone: 641-497-5291   City: New Providence Ia

(1) ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT PRAIRIELAND COOPERATIVE, NEW PROVIDENCE, IOWA

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1 requirements for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal,State and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the New Providence Volunteer Fire Department(via 911) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Hardin County, Iowa LEPC will be made.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the  hazards associated with human health and the enviroment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals(ie.,Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for the New Providence, Iowa location is Tom Catlin, location manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. In addition, the following individuals(with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:

     Dave McLean, outside operations
     Work:      ( 641)-497-5291
     24-hour:  (641)-486-5934

     Tom Catlin, location manager
     Work:     (641)-497-5291
     24-hour (641)- 497-5721

(2) Facility Information: PRAIRIELAND COOPERATIVE, NEW PROVIDENCE, IOWA IS A   STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT FOR THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.
This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

The systems co

nsists of storage tanks with asssociated piping,valves,liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment. The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis(spring and Fall). Full-time equivalent employee(FTE) numbers were computed on that basis. At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months(1/4 of the year). The FTEs for this company location is one(1).

(3) THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO:
     (a) The worst-case scenario is the failure of the one (1) 26,000 gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity) by design standard and administrative controls, resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (ammonia vapor cloud) form. According to EPA's RMP*Comp Program (Version 1.06), the distance to the endpoint is 3.6 miles.
     (b) The alternative release scenario involves the  delivery vehicle pulling away from the 1 inch line  without disconnecting the transfer hoses. The resulting release, according to EPA's RMP*Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of 0.3 mile.

(4) GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all appicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1 and state law. The ANSI Standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Administrative Code Part 21-Chapter 43-Rule 43.6(200), Standard for the "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The OSHA Standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see  Section 8.3(b). 

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, the New Providence Volunteer Fire Department has had the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammoni

a health hazard information and training provided by the company.

(5) FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
Prairieland Cooperative, New Providence, Iowa has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings.

(6) THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of Prairieland Cooperative to immmediately notify the New Providence Volunteer Fire Department and the Hardin County, Iowa LEPC, that they respond to the emergency.

(7) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
Safety is an on going process at our facility and at this time no additional changes to improve safety are evident.
